column3: Boolean flag indicating whether given set of planet parameters has been selected as default (1=yes, 0=no)
Disposition of planet according to given planet parameter set
Flag indicating whether the confirmation status of a planet has been questioned in the published literature (1=yes, 0=no)
Planet name most commonly used in the literature
Stellar name most commonly used in the literature
Letter assigned to the planetary component of a planetary system
Name of the star as given by the Henry Draper Catalog
Name of the star as given by the Hipparcos Catalog
Name of the star as given by the TESS Input Catalog
Name of the star as given by the Gaia Catalog
Number of gravitationally bound stars in the planetary system
Number of confirmed planets in the planetary system
Number of moons in the planetary system
Flag indicating whether the planet orbits a binary system (1=yes, 0=no)
Method by which the planet was first identified. How the planet was discovered. Transit Radial Velocity Microlensing Timing
Year the planet was discovered
Publication Date of the planet discovery referee publication. This is when the planet was discovered. Planet discovery date
Location of observation of planet discovery (Ground or Space)
Name of facility of planet discovery observations
Name of telescope of planet discovery observations. This is where the telescope that discovered the planet is located. Discovery telescope.
Name of instrument of planet discovery observations
Flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits radial velocity variations due to the planet (1=yes, 0=no)
Boolean flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits pulsar timing variations due to the planet (1=yes, 0=no)
Boolean flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits pulsation timing variations due to the planet (1=yes, 0=no)
Flag indicating if the planet transits its host star (1=yes, 0=no)
Flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits astrometrical variations due to the planet (1=yes, 0=no)
Flag indicating whether the planet exhibits orbital modulations on the phase curve (1=yes, 0=no)
Boolean flag indicating if the planetary system acted as a lens during an observed microlensing event (1=yes, 0=no)
Flag indicating whether a circumbinary planet that orbits an eclipsing binary induces eclipse timing variations (ETVs) in the binary pair (1=yes, 0=no)
Flag indicating if the planet has been observed via imaging techniques (1=yes, 0=no)
Boolean flag indicating if the presence of the planet was inferred due to its kinematic influence on the protoplanetary disk of its host star (1=yes, 0=no)
Time the planet takes to make a complete orbit around the host star or system
The longest radius of an elliptic orbit, or, for exoplanets detected via gravitational microlensing or direct imaging, the projected separation in the plane of the sky

Angular separation on the sky between the star and planet.Note:This may be derived in several ways, but is typically either an actual reported angular separation at a given epoch (for which the literature source will be provided in the reference column), or a calculated angular separation using the semi-major axis and the distance to the system (which may or may not be equivalent to the maximum angular separation, depending on orbital eccentricity and orientation). Refer to original data source for further information.
Radius of the planet, measured in units of radius of the Earth
Radius of the planet, measured in units of radius of Jupiter
Mass of the planet, measured in units of masses of the Earth
Mass of the planet, measured in units of masses of Jupiter
Minimum mass of a planet as measured by radial velocity, measured in units of masses of the Earth
Minimum mass of a planet as measured by radial velocity, measured in units of masses of Jupiter

A calculated quantity indicating the quotient of the lower limit of the measured planet mass, denoted as its mass times the sine of its inclination, and the sine of its inclination, measured in units of the mass of the Earth. This is specified for references in which the inclination is provided as well as the planet mass limit, but the true mass is not reported.

A calculated quantity indicating the quotient of the lower limit of the measured planet mass, denoted as its mass times the sine of its inclination, and the sine of its inclination, measured in units of the mass of Jupiter. This is specified for references in which the inclination is provided as well as the planet mass limit, but the true mass is not reported.
Best planet mass estimate available, in order of preference: Mass, M*sin(i)/sin(i), or M*sin(i), depending on availability, and measured in Earth masses
Best planet mass estimate available, in order of preference: Mass, M*sin(i)/sin(i), or M*sin(i), depending on availability, and measured in Jupiter masses
Provenance of the measurement of the best mass. Options are: Mass, M*sin(i)/sin(i), and M*sini
Amount of mass per unit of volume of the planet
Amount by which the orbit of the planet deviates from a perfect circle
Insolation flux is another way to give the equilibrium temperature. It's given in units relative to those measured for the Earth from the Sun.

The equilibrium temperature of the planet as modeled by a black body heated only by its host star, or for directly imaged planets, the effective temperature of the planet required to match the measured luminosity if the planet were a black body
Angle of the plane of the orbit relative to the plane perpendicular to the line-of-sight from Earth to the object
The time given by the average of the time the planet begins to cross the stellar limb and the time the planet finishes crossing the stellar limb.

Flag indicating if the planet orbit exhibits transit timing variations from another planet in the system (1=yes, 0=no).Note:Non-transiting planets discovered via the transit timing variations of another planet in the system will not have their TTV flag set, since they do not themselves demonstrate TTVs.
The sky-projected distance between the center of the stellar disc and the center of the planet disc at conjunction, normalized by the stellar radius
The size of the relative flux decrement caused by the orbiting body transiting in front of the star
The length of time from the moment the planet begins to cross the stellar limb to the moment the planet finishes crossing the stellar limb

column2: Ratio of Semi-Major Axis to Stellar Radius
column3: The distance between the planet and the star at mid-transit divided by the stellar radius. For the case of zero orbital eccentricity, the distance at mid-transit is the semi-major axis of the planetary orbit.

column2: Ratio of Planet to Stellar Radius
column3: The planet radius divided by the stellar radius
Depth of occultation of secondary eclipse
The time of the planet's periastron passage

The angular separation between the orbit's ascending node and periastron. Note: there are a varying conventions in the exoplanet literature regarding argument of periastron (or periapsis). For example, some publications refer the planet's orbit, others to the host star's reflex orbit, which differs by 180 deg. The values in the Exoplanet Archive are not corrected to a standardized system, but are as-reported for each publication.
Half the peak-to-peak amplitude of variability in the stellar radial velocity

The angle between the angular momentum vector of the rotation of the host star and the angular momentum vector of the orbit of the planet, projected into the plane of the sky. Depending on the choice of coordinate system, projected obliquity is represented in the literature as either lambda (λ) or beta (β), where λ is defined as the negative of β (i.e., λ = -β). Since λ is reported more often than β, all values of β have been converted to λ.
The angle between the angular momentum vector of the rotation of the host star and the angular momentum vector of the orbit of the planet
Classification of the star based on their spectral characteristics following the Morgan-Keenan system
Temperature of the star as modeled by a black body emitting the same total amount of electromagnetic radiation
Length of a line segment from the center of the star to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Sun
Amount of matter contained in the star, measured in units of masses of the Sun
Measurement of the metal content of the photosphere of the star as compared to the hydrogen content
Ratio for the Metallicity Value ([Fe/H] denotes iron abundance, [M/H] refers to a general metal content)
Amount of energy emitted by a star per unit time, measured in units of solar luminosities
Gravitational acceleration experienced at the stellar surface
The age of the host star
Amount of mass per unit of volume of the star
Rotational velocity at the equator of the star multiplied by the sine of the inclination
Reference of publication used for given parameter set
The time required for the planet host star to complete one rotation, assuming it is a solid body
Velocity of the star in the direction of the line of sight
Angular change in position over time as seen from the center of mass of the Solar System
Angular change in right ascension over time as seen from the center of mass of the Solar System
Angular change in declination over time as seen from the center of mass of the Solar System
Reference of publication used for given parameter set
Distance to the planetary system in units of parsecs
Difference in the angular position of a star as measured at two opposite positions within the Earth's orbit
Number of Notes associated with the planet. View all notes in the Confirmed Planet Overview page.
